comment._content: Shop was in Broad Street Waterford

comment.author: 24474458@N08
comment._content: Love it...did it change its name to Torries in the 50s I wonder......

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24474458@N08] Well, that's interesting now. Had a lot of info coming in on members of the Torrie family over the last couple of days. There's a Peg Torrie in this photo. You could be right if The Home & Colonial Stores became an L & N shop. The last L & N in Waterford was on Broad Street, and it closed in 1986.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wikipedia article on the Home and Colonial Stores . They specialized in tea (1/4 per lb here). Stores all over the UK using that logo - eventually merged into Safeways. The faces on those shop assistants at large size! Golly, I find myself sucked right into these old photos ,,, and wanting a cup of tea!

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: The main L&N shop was on the opposite side of Broad Street to the. Home and Colonial The L&N had a huge network of shops all owned by the Torrie family. The shops were in several locations in Waterford city and in almost every town in the south east.The business was sold to Super Valu in the 1980s.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04]desmondg47 - You might know for sure if this is the building - Google Street View - g.co/maps/kf9ef . See also the pigs who hang around next door neighbours - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6781897522/]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Ah, thank you! That clarifies the Torrie question for [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24474458@N08] at any rate...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content: In the glass name sign above the window you can see glimpses reflected of the shop across the street.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content:
NLI,
The main L&N shop was on the west side of Broad Street approx half way between Patrick Street and Little Patrick Street.That whole side of Broad Street has since been redeveloped. 
I did mean to say that the company traded until it was sold under the name L&N, but the operating company was actually owned by the Torrie family, and it was Adam F. Torrie. Ltd.
DG47

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] So, how are we for the location on this one then? And indeed J. Morgan next door. I really just plopped them down on Broad Street to establish a location, however inaccurately. Both of these shops would be on the left going up the hill?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Home and Colonial was on east side of Broad Street, number3. Morgan's number 4. The numbering started at the junction of Peter Street with number 1 and ascended north along Broad Street towards Arundel Lane and  then crossed across the street. By going up the hill, I presume you mean traveling from the river side. That would be correct.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Terrific, that tallies with the Google Street View link above.  I wasn't 100% sure.  What a relief!  [celebrates with another cup of tea]

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content: My wife worked in various Home & Colonial shops in London in the 1960s.  Around the late sixties the shops became Liptons.
